@lavueltablog @BaruchCollege @Baruch_Weissman @Baruch_CTL @JCBLibrary This time we used Tulane's great photo collection. Overall, its a nice option that encourages critical thinking and student-led research, but is fairly low-stress and can be done asynchronously to make lemonade out of the lemons of having to teach online.

@lavueltablog @BaruchCollege @Baruch_Weissman @Baruch_CTL Once I had a handle on the site, I created a series of module, asynchronous assignments (about one every 4 weeks) in which I introduce students to an online archive. Students then must select one archival doc/image and analyze it using our class readings and discussions

@lavueltablog @BaruchCollege @Baruch_Weissman Sure! Baruch has a great platform, Blogs at Baruch, which is a wordpress template that is ready-to-go for us (so even a tech-challenged person like me can operate it). @Baruch_CTL has also been great at giving tutorials in how to use the platform.

To my friends at @BaruchCollege: the silver-lining of my COVID delayed Fulbright Fellowship is that I will be teaching  Intellectual Property (Law 3118) next semester: Tuesdays and Thursdays at 9:05 AM.  Join me on Zoom over breakfast for some fun with trademarks and copyrights.

I was asked to update the material for an advanced undergraduate seminar I teach in Spring 2021 @BaruchCollege. 
My response:
I'm waiting for the US Presidential election. The seminar will either be called "Democratization" or "Authoritarianism in the Global North."

"Most elected officials don't want a lot of people voting," @JumaaneWilliams answering @BaruchCollege @aagabor  student question on voting process in NYC during #PresidentialElection2020. That's why you should vote, he says. His tips: vote early (starting Oct 24), vote absentee
